subject: Add multi-host postcode support
commitMessage:
Add multi-host postcode support

These changes add the multiple host postcode implementation. In addition to the
LPC snoop the postcode can be read via D-Bus interface.The same is displayed
in seven segment display thorough GPIO lines.

The design can be refered at
   https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/35065

Tested:

 Verified in Facebook Tiogapass & Yosemitev2.

1.The postcode displayed in the seven segment corresponding to the
  host position selected in the frontpanel of Facebook yosemitev2(4 host).

2.The postcode history is verified in the respective host directory
     "/var/lib/phosphor-post-code-manager/hostX(1,2,3,4)".

Signed-off-by: Kumar Thangavel <thangavel.k@hcl.com>
Change-Id: Id79ad00652bfedd319d3b8ccf1aafbdc60b33d86

Patch Set 11:

This patch is dependent on the patch in phosphor-dbus-interfaces (https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/38385).
For now, setting this review as WIP. Once dependency patch is merged, will set this review to active.
Absolutely not.  There is no assurance that the host numbers are 1-N.  This is why we have the HOST_INSTANCES variable.
Ack. Missed to change HOST_INSTANCE as got this comment in meta-phosphor patch. Will update in the PS.
'const' is redundant when you already have 'constexpr'

Is there even a reason to call this "ipmi snoop"?  That seems like the implementation, but this code would work 100% the same if there were a (for example) PLDM implementation of the same interface, right?
There is a sdbusplus helper for PropertiesChanged signals, please use that rather than creating your own.
Why are we restricting post codes to 1 byte?  AMD uses 32 or 64 bit post codes.
This implies that 0xFF is an invalid post code.  Is that true?

Is there a good reason to mix using the sdbuspp-generated classes and the boost code?  This is a little confusing to me.


Why do we need this async_get?  Can't we simply listen to a PropertyChanged signal for the selector?
How do we know this ends up being the service name?  Can we use mapper instead of hard-coding service names?
Suggest setting [[nodiscard]] on this so that the bug that you have on line 173 doesn't happen.

Rather than control these GPIOs from userspace like this, there was once a proposal for a 7-segment display driver in the kernel.  Can you follow up what happened with it?

https://lore.kernel.org/openbmc/CANsWYUW3sdbUguaOOMLkvbaTOHsCMBo8n0CDpVYiSkbZBuRThQ@mail.gmail.com/

I think the '7seg.cpp' is also related to this.

This driver is related to 7seg only. But they are using 16 bits for displaying values in 7 Seg.
they use abcdefg pins of 7 segment. But our LCD debugcard needs 8 bits only. We can't use this driver.
GPIOs like this should be defined in https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/designs/device-tree-gpio-naming.md.
You are getting a lambda here and then doing nothing with it.  I suspect that isn't what you intended.

I don't understand how this is expected to work.  You did an async call on line 169 to get the latest value of the selector, but you do nothing here to wait for it, so you are guaranteed to always be using the *old* value of the selector, aren't you?

Don't you need to do something to update the postCodeDisplay to the current host whenever the selector changes as well?  Otherwise the 7 seg display will continue to display a post code for the previously selected host, which is pretty confusing to a human.

I'm relatively confused here.  Aren't we missing this whole transformation?

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seven-segment_display#Hexadecimal
Ack. Our LCD Debug card converts 8 bits data and directly displaying the postcodes in the 7seg display.
I don't think this is accurate anymore.  Is it really "TOTAL HOST" or is it a per-instance number for this daemon?
Does this break current users in any way?  Are there any recipe updates or service file updates we need to do to make sure this is '0' by default?
Yes. In the recipe, they should have OBMC_HOST_INSTANCES by default as "0".

How do you know they are listed "1 2 3" and not "3 2 1"?

What happens if the list is "1 3 5"?  Do we end up creating useless handlers for 2/4?

No. Count the instances based on the delimiter(space).
"1 2 3" and "3 2 1"  = 3.
"1 3 5" = 3. 

Two terms : total number of host and instance.
total number of host - based on the delimiter we can count.
Instance - we need to parse from the obmc-host-instances.

Now, we are getting both number of host and instances
This makes it seem like you should #ifdef around device on line 183 also, right?
There is some bad behavior here that '-d foo' ends up causing '-v' when ENABLE_IPMI_SNOOP is on (inadvertent fall-through).

Why do we have two different constants here?  Can you refactor this so that 'lpcsnoop' and 'ipmisnoop' both append the appropriate host value from `-h`?  Please refactor this code so that the 'lpcsnoop' is all inside a function similar to the one here for 'postCodeIpmiHandler'.  I think this will make it so that the only difference is which handler function you're calling here.

Why?

And why are we mixing printf and cout?
It appears that only ipmisnoop.hpp utilizes libgpiod.  Should this (and/or libgpiodcxx) only be used when the ipmisnoop is enabled?
Why do we need both?  Doesn't libgpiodcxx depend on libgpiod itself?
C++ functions like line bulk objects needs libgpiodcxx. If we provide only libgpiod, it not accepts C++ API's.

That tells me why we need libgpiodcxx, but do we also need libgpiod?  It seems like you should only need one of the dependencies.  dbus-sensors, for instance, also does GPIO access but only uses libgpiodcxx.

Since the code already has 'lpcsnoop', I would suggest that 'snoop' is not a great name for this.

Should ipmi and lpc snoop be incompatible or can both be enabled at the same time?  You may need two different options for 'lpcsnoop' and 'ipmisnoop' (and use some meson settings to ensure only one can be set) or else have a single 'snoop' option which is configurable with a set `{ 'lpc', 'ipmi' }`.

Do we need to do any refactoring to the code so that lpcsnoop is disabled when ipmisnoop is enabled?

Single snoop option configure with lpc or ipmi.

Do we need to do any refactoring to the code so that lpcsnoop is disabled when ipmisnoop is enabled?  --> No I think, Based on the compiler option any one snoop should be enabled.
It appears that the rest of the options have taken to use dashes and not underscores.
